resources.string:
Welcome to the Quick Mobility Check! This quick assessment will help you identify areas of your body that may need more attention in terms of flexibility and mobility.
You’ll be guided through a series of simple exercises that test the mobility of your hips, hamstrings, shoulders, and posture. Each exercise is easy to perform and only takes a few minutes. Based on your results, we’ll recommend the most suitable flexibility and mobility goals for you to focus on.

Let’s get started and discover how you can improve your movement and overall well-being!

Welcome to Mobify, your personalized mobile app designed to enhance your flexibility and mobility. Whether you\'re aiming to overcome stiffness, improve your range of motion, or achieve specific fitness goals, Mobify offers tailored training programs and routines just for you. Start by identifying your areas of improvement, set your goals, and let Mobify guide you through a step-by-step journey to better movement. With easy-to-follow exercises, progress tracking, and daily reminders, Mobify is here to support your path to a more flexible and active lifestyle. Unlock your full potential with Mobify!
Do you want to choose your goals or perform a quick mobility check if you are not clear about them?
You have to select at least 1 goal
You can only select up to 3 goals
Remember to do your mobility routine.
We need your permission to send notifications. Please enable notifications on the next screen.
Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Slowly rotate your leg inward and then outward while keeping your torso straight.
Full range of motion with ease
Stand with your feet together and slowly bend forward at the hips, trying to touch your toes without bending your knees.
Can reach just above my toes
Reach one hand over your shoulder and the other hand behind your back, trying to make your hands touch.
Hands are close but not touching
Stand with your heels, back, and head against a wall. Try to lift your arms overhead without moving your head or back away from the wall.
Can fully extend arms without losing contact
Cannot fully extend arms without losing contact

Based on your results, we haven\'t been able to determine a clear recommendation since you scored the same on three or more exercises, feel free to choose the objective that best suits your preferences.
Based on your results, we recommend focusing on
30 day pancake with PNF and loaded stretching
This training plan will help you improve your hip mobility. It is designed to do three workouts per week for four weeks.
This training plan will help you improve your hamstring flexibility. It is designed to do three workouts per week for four weeks.
This training plan will help you improve your shoulder mobility. It is designed to do three workouts per week for four weeks.
This training plan will help you improve your posture and spinal mobility. It is designed to do three workouts per week for four weeks.
This training plan will help you improve your squat. Do a workout before your squat or squat pattern training.

This mobility plan is designed for individuals who spend long hours sitting and are looking to improve the flexibility and health of their quads, hips, shoulders, and back. In just 8 minutes a day, 3-4 times per week, these targeted exercises help to relieve muscle tension, improve posture, and prevent common aches associated with a sedentary lifestyle. Perfect for incorporating into your daily routine, this plan helps maintain overall mobility and physical well-being.

This full-body flexibility plan is designed for beginners to improve flexibility and mobility throughout the entire body.\nIt is recommended to perform this routine 3 to 4 times per week.\nYou shouldn’t feel pain during the stretches, but discomfort is okay. Always breathe deeply and focus on gradually increasing your range of motion over time.

This plan is ideal for beginners who want to work on flexibility with a focus on specific areas of the body. The upper-lower split routine allows you to alternate between days targeting the upper body and lower body, which helps to break down the stretches into manageable sessions while focusing on flexibility gains.\nPerform the upper body routine one day and the lower body routine the next, alternating between the two. Aim to do this routine 3 to 4 times a week.\nYou shouldn’t feel pain during the stretches, but discomfort is okay. Always breathe deeply and focus on gradually increasing your range of motion over time.

The objective of this routine is to be able to touch your toes with straight legs. For the following 28 days do everyday workout 1 or workout 2, you can either choose one and do it every day or change between them. Take a picture of the before and after so you can see the progess made!

Achieving a perfect pancake stretch (where your torso can lay flat between your legs in a seated straddle) requires a combination of passive flexibility, active flexibility, and strength in end ranges. Incorporating PNF (Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation) and loaded stretching will accelerate your progress by enhancing both your passive and active flexibility while developing strength in deeper ranges of motion.\\n\\n Train 4 times per week for best results, each workout lasts 20-30 minutes.\\n\\nOn week 1 you will build the fundations and introduce PNF Stretching. On week 2 you will introduce deeper loaded stretches. On week 3 you will increase intensity for PNF and loaded stretching and on week 4 you will perform peak training.
Stand with your feet hip-width apart, shift your weight onto one leg and slightly bend the oher. Keep your back straight while hinging at your hips. Use your hamstring to pull yourself back up.
Assume a lunge position with one leg forward and the other backward. Lower your body down and lean forward. Push back up to the starting position.

Sit on the ground and open your legs as wide as possible into a straddle position. Lean forward at your hips, trying to reach as far as you can in front of you. Keep your back straight and chest open.
Get on the ground with one knee bent in front of you and the other leg behind you slightly bent. Lean into the front knee lowering your upper body toward the ground.
Stand with your feet hip-width apart and extend one arm in front of you. Swing that leg up in front of you and back down while keeping you leg as straight as possible and your toes pointed up.
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outward. Lower into a deep squat position, keeping your back straight and chest up. Stand back up to the starting position.
Step one leg forward into a lunge position, keeping the back leg extended and the knee off the ground. Sink your hips down and forward to stretch the hip flexors.
Sit with the soles of your feet together and your knees ot to the sides. Hold your feet and bring them as coles to you as you can. Gently press your knees toward the ground.
Sit with one leg bent in front and the other bent behind you. Rotate your hips to switch the position of your legs, keeping both knees at 90-degree angles while switching sides.
Stand and open your legs as wide as possible into a straddle position. Then bend at the hips, pushing them back while keeping your back straight.
Sit on the ground with one leg bent and the other ankle crossed over the opposite knee. Gently pull the leg underneath toward you or press down on the top knee to stretch the hip and glutes.
Kneel on one knee with the other leg bent at 90 degrees in front. Push your hips forward to stretch the front of the hip and thigh.
Hinge at your hips until you feel a stretch behind your knees. Bend one leg while the other is straight then fluidly bend the other knee while straightening the first knee.

Kneel on the ground facing away from a wall, place one foot against the wall with the knee bent at 90 degrees. Tuck your pelvis and lean slightly forward with your body upright to stretch the hip flexor.
Sit on the ground with one leg straight out in front of you and the other leg bent in toward you. Reach forward with both hands, trying to touch the toes of your straight leg.
Lie face down on the ground, place hands under shoulders in a plank position. Lift your upper body off the ground, arching your back.
Get into a deep squat position and walk forward, staying low to the ground to stretch the hips and improve mobility.
Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed slightly outward. Hinge at your hips and lower your upper body towards the ground, keeping your back straight and chest open.
Sit with one leg bent in front and the other bent behind you. Lift your body off the ground while keeping your knees on the ground then lower back down.
Stand with your back against a wall and lower into a deep squat position. Use the wall for support and gently push your knees away from your body.
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, shift your weight to one side lowering into a squat while keeping the other leg straight. In one motion, return to starting position and switch sides.
Stand with feet hip-width apart and make circular motions with your hips, going clockwise and then counterclockwise. Gradually increase the size of the circles.
Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed outward. Lower into a wide squat position, keeping your back straight while pushing your knees out.
Stand with feet together, hinge at the hips, and reach forward along your legs to stretch the hamstrings. Keep your back straight and chest open.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and extend one arm in front of you. Swing that leg up in front of you and back down while keeping your leg as straight as possible and your toes pointed up. Repeat with the other leg.

Stand with your feet close together. Hinge at your hips and lower your upper body towards your toes. Reach your hands towards your feet, try to touch your toes, the ground, or as far down your legs as you can comfortably go.

Stand with your feet more than shoulder-width apart (wider stance) and place your hands on your hips. Hinge at your hips and lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight then come back up.
Sit on the ground with on leg straight out in front of you and the other leg bent in toward you. Reach forward with both hands, trying to touch the toes of your straight leg.
Sit on the ground with your legs extended straight in front of you. Reach both hands forward, trying to reach past your toes or as far as you can go. Return to te starting position and repeat.
Sit on the ground with your legs extended straight in front of you. Reach both hands forward, trying to reach past your toes or as far as you can go.
Hold onto a wall or something near you for support. Swing one leg across the front of your body, then back and out to the side. Repeat while slowly increasing your range of motion.

Sit on the ground and bend one leg, bringing your knee toward you. Place your hand behind your hamstring and gently pull your leg toward your chest, feeling a stretch in the back of your thigh. Straighten your leg, extending up toward the celing.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and slowly roll your upper body forward, one vertebra at a time, until your hands touch the ground as far as you can comfortably go. Roll back up to the starting position in the same controlled manner.
While standing, cross one leg behind the other (keep this leg straight). Reach downward and try to touch the toes of that leg. Slightly bend the other legs so that so can bend down.
Stand with your feet shoulder widthapart and swing your arms across the front of your body until they reach the opposite side, then swing back in one continuous movement.

Sit on the edge of a sturdy chair and grip the front edge of the seat with your hands. Move your body off the chair and lower to the ground by bending your elbows, then push yourself back up to the starting position.

Begin like a chair dip by sitting on the edge of a chair with gands in front of you. Move your body off the chair and lower to the ground by bending your elbow. Hold this position, then push yourself back up.

Place your hands shoulder width apart on a chair or counter in front of you. Then, lower your heand and chest towards the ground, feeling the stretch in your shoulders and upper back. Hold for a few seconds before returning to the starting position.
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms out to your sides. Make large circular motions with your arms. Reverse the direction of the circles after a few repetitions.
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms out to your sides. Point thumbs back with palms facing up then pulse your hands backward using small, rapid movements.
Grasp your arms behind your back. Gently pull them up towards your upper back, feeling the stretch in your bicep. Hold for a few seconds before releasing.
Stand facing an open doorway and place your hands on either side of the doorframe. Lean forward to feel the stretch in your chest and shoulders.

Hold a broomstick or resistance band with your hands shoulder-width apart. Slowly raise the stick above your head and behind your back, feeling the stretch in your shoulders and chest. Reverse the movement to come back to the starting position.
Lay with your upper body on a chair or bench. Raise your arms straight up while holding a weight then slowly bring them down to above your head or as far as you can.
Place your hands on a counter or study surface behind you with palms facing down. Lower your body to feel the stretch in your shoulders and biceps.
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms above your head. Reach one arm higher than the other using your shoulders and upper body, alternate sides.
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and exend one arm above your head. Lean toward the opposite side to feel the stretch. Hold for a few seconds before repeating on the other side.

Hold a broomstick or resistance band with your hands shoulder-width apart. Slowly raise the stick above your head and behind your back, hold the broomstick behind your back, feeling the stretch in your chest.
Sit on a chair, place hands on the backrest, and gently arch your upper back to push your chest forward. Hold for a few seconds to stretch the front of the body.
Sit on the ground, extend legs straight in front, and reach forward towards toes, trying to touch them. Keep your back straight and hold targeting your lower back.
Stand facing a wall, place your elbows on the wall above shoulder height. Take a step back and lean your upper body into the wall.
Stand against a wall, bend elbows at 90 degrees, and slowly slide them up and down the wall. Maintain contact with the wall especially elbows and writst throughout.

Sit on the ground with your legs crossed. Twist your torso to the side, using your arm for leverage, this is a passive stretch. Hold the twist, then switch sides to release tension in the back and spine.
Get on hands and knees, arch your back up like a cat with your head facing down, and the arch it down like a cow. Flow smoothly from one position to the other.
Lie face down, hands next to shoulders or under your head, and lift upper body off the ground. Lower back down and repeat.
Stand or sit with a straight back, tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. You can user your hands to gently pull your head closer to your shoulder.
Stand facing away a wall and gently arch your back to place your hands on the wall behind you. Walk them down as far as you are able to.
Stand next to a wall and place your forearm against it while keeping your arm straight. Gently lean forward to stretch your chest.
Sit on the ground with your legs crossed. Twist your torso to the side and hold yourself in that position (without using arms for leverage). This is an active stretch.
Stand with feet hip-width apart or sit, and reach one arm overhead. Lean over in the direction of your arm to feel the stretch in your side.
Get on hands and knees then arch your back up like a cat with your head facing down.
Get on hands and knees then arch your back down like a cow with your head looking straight.
kneel with a chair in front of you and place your elbows on the back of the chair. Lower your head and chest toward the ground.

Sit with straight back then hold a broomstick behind your shoulder. Grab the back of the broomstick with your hand so that your arm is now wrapped around it. Gently pull the broomstick up from the bottom.
Start on hands and knees, reach one arm under your body and across the ground, resting your shoulder and ear on the ground. Hold this position.
Step into a lunge position, reach one arm overhead, and lean over in the direction of your arm to feel the stretch in your side and hip.
Stand with your back straight and your hand on your hip. Place your other hand on your elbow and gently pull it forward to rotate your shoulder inward.
Place the band in the exact position of the photo (not too high). The band must help you push the talus bone backward.

Start by moving slowly up and down the lower leg muscles until you find a tender area. Pause on this area and “tack it down” with your opposite leg for about ten seconds before moving to find another spot
Use a step to place your feet and put one feet back on the edge of the step to stretch the ankle.
Increase each time the range of motion to finally be able to do pistol squats to strengthen the knees.

"Start with the band pulled close to your hip joint. Assume a lunge position with the band around your forward leg. The band should be pulling laterally in this position. From this position, rock your knee inward and back ten times. With enough tension on the band, this should cause a light stretching sensation in your lateral hip. Next push your knee out to the side and back."

Address your hip flexors, quads and lateral hips. Start by moving slowly up and down the lower leg muscles until you find a tender area. Pause on this area and \"tack it down\" with your bodyweight for about ten seconds before moving again.

Start by assuming a deep lunge position with your left foot forward. Squeeze your glutes and drive your hips toward the floor. This movement should cause a stretch to be felt in the front of the right hip. Second, drop your left elbow to the ground. Hold for five seconds. Next, use your elbow or hand to drive your left knee out to the side. Make sure to keep your foot firmly planted on the ground. Finally, rotate the entire upper body up and to the left, ending with the left arm in the air. This last movement helps address the mobility of the thoracic (midspine) that is also prone to stiffness.

"To start, place an elastic band around your ankles. Next, assume an athletic single-leg stance. Once in this position, push the hips backward and allow the chest to move forward. This small movement allows us to engage our posterior chain and remain balanced. Once we are in position, kick the nonstance leg out to the side and back in a slow and controlled manner. The distance the leg moves out to the side is not our main concern. Focus on keeping the stance leg in a stable and unwavering position during the entire exercise. "

Step 1: Lie on the ground with your back to the floor. Your knees can stay bent for comfort. Step 2: Activate the muscles on all sides of your core, a process called co-contraction. A verbal cue I like to use is to brace yourself as if you were about to receive a punch to the gut. This should create a feeling of firmness around your entire lower torso. Place your hands on your stomach and on your side. You should feel the muscles under your hands tense as they activate. Improper bracing will only activate our rectus abdominus (our sixpack muscle).

Step 1: From the all-fours position (quadruped), place a PVC pipe or cane along the back as shown. At all times, the PVC should be in contact with the back to ensure proper spinal alignment. Step 2: Once you find the neutral position, re-create that co-contraction of the core you learned from level one. This bracing effort will create the stability needed for the next few steps. Step 3: Next, lift your arms up toward your head (one at a time) and back toward the starting position by your side. During this arm movement, your lower back should remain in a stable, braced position. It is important to breathe first and then brace your core. Don’t hold your breath during this movement. Let your breath out slowly through pursed lips (as if you have a straw in your mouth). Step 4: Once this stage is mastered, the second step is to perform the movement with one leg at a time. Step 5: The next stage is one where both the legs and arms are moving. Start by moving your right arm and left leg at the same time. Step 6: The last stage is where the arm and leg on the same side are moving

Step 1: Assume a front squat position with the bar held on top of the chest and shoulders. Step 2: Take your hands away from the bar and hold them out in front of you. This should look like the starting position of the bodyweight squat. Step 3: Use the proper breathing and bracing pattern to stabilize your core properly. Take a big breath into your stomach followed by a strong brace of your core muscles. Step 4: Next, perform the front squat to full depth while trying to maintain the bar in the same position. In order to stay balanced, the bar must track over the middle of your foot the entire time. Inability to adequately maintain core stability and stay balanced will force the arms to fall forward. This will cause the bar to roll off the shoulders and drop to the ground.

Start in a kneeling position. Sit your hips back on your feet and push your hands out in front of you (one hand on top of the other). Next, let your chest drop down to the floor. Continue to reach with your arms together overhead while you let your breath out slowly. Try to sink your chest toward the ground.

Find a corner in the room you are in. Stand with your arms out to the side in an L position. Place your hands on the walls and slowly push into the corner. Make sure to keep your lower back from hyper-extending during this movement. You should feel a good stretch in your chest the more you push into the corner.

Start by lying on your stomach with your arms in an L position out to the side. While focusing on your midback, perform a small chin tuck and lift your head off the ground. Hold this position while focusing on activating the muscles in between your shoulder blades for ten seconds.

Step 1: (Row) Grab a resistance band with your right hand. Pull the band toward you in a rowing motion. Your hand should finish directly in front of your elbow with your arm parallel to the ground. This engages the muscles that stabilize the shoulder blade. Step 2: (External rotation) From this position, rotate the shoulder backward. Your hand should now be facing the ceiling with your elbow bent to ninety degrees like an L. Step 3: (Press) Next, push your hand overhead and hold for five seconds. The muscles that stabilize the shoulder blade should be working hard to keep your arm from falling forward. Step 4: Next, reverse the pattern and return to the start position. Lower the arm to the L position. Rotate forward until your arm is parallel to the ground. Finally, press your arm forward to end the movement.

While seated in a chair, place your ankle over your opposite knee, keeping your back straight. Lean forward and grab the leg of the chair with your hands to assist in lowering your torso. You can also add weight to your hands to increase the intensity.

Place your knee and ankle in a straight line on a chair, with the other foot grounded and the leg as low as possible. Perform repetitions by leaning backward and downward, then forward diagonally. Do 10 repetitions and then hold at the forward position 10-30 seconds.
While lying face down with your arms extended overhead, lift your arms and move them in an internal rotation towards your back, then return to the starting position through external rotation.
Kneeling Hip Flexor Stretch with Knee Flexion

Place your knee on a comfortable surface. Lean forward and bend your knee, holding it with your hand on the same side. Apply pressure as if you were trying to extend the knee, and gradually open up the hip.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Extend your arms upward and backward, arching your upper back and shoulders. Hold the position for 10, then 20, and finally 30 seconds, gradually increasing the stretch.
Stand with your feet hip-width apart, gently arch your spine backward, lifting your chest and keeping your hips forward. Hold the position for 10, then 20, and 30 seconds.
Stand tall and bring your hands behind your back, clasping your fingers together. Stretch your arms down and backward, opening up your chest and shoulders. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.

Lying on your back, extend your arms to the sides in a \"T\" shape. Cross one leg over your body to the opposite side, allowing your hips to twist while keeping your shoulders grounded. Hold for 10, 20, and 30 seconds.

Standing, extend one arm in front of you with the palm facing up. Use your other hand to gently pull the fingers down and back, stretching the wrist and biceps muscles. Hold for 10, 20, and 30 seconds.
Standing, place one foot on a chair and stretch your leg as you lean your torso forward, trying to reach the raised leg. Feel the stretch in your hamstrings. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.
Kneel with one knee on the ground and the other foot forward. Push your hips forward, feeling the stretch in your hip flexors. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.

Sit with your legs open in a \"V\" shape and slowly lean your torso forward, aiming to touch the ground with your chest. Feel the stretch in your hamstrings and lower back. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.

Sit with the soles of your feet together and your knees falling to the sides. Use your hands to gently push your knees down, feeling the stretch in your inner thighs. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.

Place your hands on a chair for support and step one leg back with the heel on the ground. Lean forward over your front leg, feeling the stretch in the calf of the back leg. Hold for 10, 20, and then 30 seconds.

Start with both legs in front of you. Put one heel in a sliding surface and fold the other leg to the side. Pull your trunk onto your thigh and use the quadriceps to slide your foot away. Straighten the back on breath in, press hill down into floor and extend your leg on breath out.

Bent one knee and raise your other leg. Straighten the leg that is in contact with the floor for two seconds and look down behind you, ideally touching the floor with your hands. Bent and repeat all over until time is over

Begin in a quadruped position, on your hands and knees. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, lift one leg and draw large circles with your knee. Move slowly and focus on controlling the motion from your hip joint. Perform the circles in both directions, and then switch to the other leg.

Start in a standing position and step one foot forward, lowering your hips towards the ground. Drop your back knee to the floor while keeping your front knee bent at a 90-degree angle. Make sure your front knee is aligned with your ankle. Press your hips forward to stretch the hip flexors. Hold the position and then switch legs.

Sit with your legs spread wide and hinge forward from your hips.\nLoaded Stretch Variation: Hold a light weight (e.g., 2-5 kg) or a kettlebell in front of you to add gentle pressure as you lean forward.\nPNF Method: Press your hands or elbows into the ground while resisting with your legs (contract), then relax and sink deeper for 10-15 seconds. Repeat for 2-3 cycles.

From all fours, slide one knee forward and the opposite leg back, lowering your hips. This opens the hip flexors and glutes.\nPNF Method: Press your front knee into the floor for 5 seconds, then relax and go deeper.

Sit with the soles of your feet together and your knees dropping out to the sides.\nPNF Method: Press your knees down with your hands or elbows, resist for 5-10 seconds, then relax and let the knees fall lower. Repeat 2 cycles.

Stand with legs wide apart, hinge from your hips, and fold forward. You can place your hands on the floor or blocks.\nLoaded Variation: Hold light dumbbells or a barbell for gentle weight pulling you deeper into the stretch.

Sit in a wide straddle, with your hands behind you or in front of you. Lift one leg at a time off the ground while keeping it straight. This strengthens hip flexors and improves active range of motion.
Lying on your back, bring one knee across your body to release the lower back.

Sit with legs as wide as possible. Hold a light weight or kettlebell (3-5 kg) in front of you.\nPNF Method: Push your hands into the floor while resisting with your legs for 5-10 seconds. Relax and lean forward deeper for 15-20 seconds. Repeat 2-3 cycles.\nLoaded Stretch: Allow the weight to gently pull your torso forward while keeping your back straight.
Kneel with knees spread wide, feet out, and hips lowering towards the floor.\nPNF Method: Press knees into the floor for 5-10 seconds, then relax and sink lower. Repeat 2 cycles.
Sit on a yoga block or pillow to elevate your hips. This helps improve the anterior tilt of your pelvis, allowing a deeper stretch. Hold a weight in front for added load.
Stand with feet wide, then squat down to one side while keeping the other leg straight.

Sit with the soles of your feet together and let your knees drop out to the sides. Hold your feet with your hands and gently hinge forward from your hips, keeping your back straight as you fold over your legs. Hold the stretch for the desired time, focusing on breathing deeply and relaxing your hips.
Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at a 90-degree angle. Push back up to the starting position and repeat
Hold a light dumbbell or kettlebell to add load while moving side to side.
Sit in the pancake position and hover just above the floor, engaging the hip flexors and core to hold your torso up.
Do both legs and each leg front and side
